stem: A 58-year-old male presents to the ED with crushing chest pain radiating to his left jaw. Review the provided information, including the 12-Lead EKG and Cardiac Biomarker Panel. Select the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two essential parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
Background: History of hypertension and smoking. Pain started 30 minutes ago while shoveling snow; rated 10/10.
Assessment: Diaphoretic and clutching chest (Levine's sign).
Recommendation: Initiate standard ACS protocol.

tabs.title: 12-Lead EKG & Biomarkers
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 164/98, HR 108, RR 24, SpO2 92% on room air.

rationale.correct: The client's crushing chest pain and ST-elevation in leads V2-V4 on the EKG indicate an acute anterior STEMI (c2). The priority is rapid intervention to restore blood flow. Administering chewable aspirin (a1) helps prevent further clot formation, and preparing the client for emergent cardiac catheterization (a2) allows for prompt reperfusion. Continuous ST-segment monitoring (p1) and serial Troponin I levels (p2) are crucial for assessing the extent of myocardial damage and detecting potential complications.
clinicalPearls: Chewing aspirin facilitates faster absorption through the buccal mucosa compared to swallowing.
The left anterior descending (LAD) artery supplies the anterior wall of the heart; occlusion is often referred to as the 'widowmaker'.
While morphine can be used for pain refractory to nitroglycerin, recent studies suggest it may delay aspirin absorption. Therefore, oxygen, nitroglycerin, and aspirin are prioritized.

questionTrap.trap: Delaying cardiac catheterization until Troponin results are available.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: ST-elevation on the EKG is diagnostic for STEMI. Reperfusion therapy should be initiated immediately without waiting for blood results.

mnemonic.title: MONA TASS
mnemonic.expansion: M-Morphine (for pain refractory to Nitro). O-Oxygen. N-Nitroglycerin. A-Aspirin. T-Thrombolytics (if PCI unavailable). A-Anticoagulants. S-Stool softeners. S-Sedatives (for anxiety).
